headline: Hummus III
description: As a spread, dip or garlicky pita filling, classic hummus is both delicious and satisfying. Best of all, it's whipped up in seconds in a blender or food processor.

video.description: Use canned garbanzo beans to whip up an easy, tasty hummus at home.
video.name: Hummus III

name: Hummus III

recipeInstructions.text: Place the garbanzo beans, tahini, lemon juice, salt and garlic in a blender or food processor. Blend until smooth. Transfer mixture to a serving bowl.
Drizzle olive oil over the garbanzo bean mixture. Sprinkle with paprika and parsley.

review.reviewBody: Great basic recipe. Super easy, quick and my kids love it. Used a blender and it worked great. I roasted sesame seeds instead of tahini. Next will try adding roasted red pepper!
I've been making this for years, the recipe is perfect. I do boil my garbanzo beans for about 7 minutes to enure the texture of the Hummus is smooth.
Removed shells from chick peas and added 1/2 tsp cumin. Fresh Italian parsley topped it off. Fantastic!

This tastes so good. I lived in the Holy Land for two years and I had hummus several times a week, every week. This recipe is as good as any hummus I've had anywhere. I cooked 1 lb of dried chickpeas the day before, after soaking them the night before that. (Any kind of cooked dry beans are always better the day after you cook them.) I used 2 cups of the cooked chickpeas and thinned them with some of the delicious broth. I added ¼ tsp of ground red pepper and a few shakes of black pepper. The chickpeas I cooked already had a lot of garlic and lemon, so I didn't add any additional garlic and I used about half the lemon juice called for in this recipe. I used ⅓ cup of tahini, and salted to taste. Great recipe. Now I'm off to make some Arabic salad and baba ghanoush to go with the hummus.
Best recipe for hummus I have ever tried. Well worth the bother of finding the tahini.
Excellent hummus recipe! This is a keeper!

Used only 2 tbsp of tahini and added 1/2 tsp of cumin as other reviewers suggested. By accident, I added the tablespoon of olive oil to the main ingredients, and I also saved the garbanzo liquid and added in a bit during the blending process. It came out great!

Absolutely the BEST hummus recipe. I've made it using black beans, garbanzo beans & a combination of the two. One thing I've found that makes a lot of difference in the flavor is, use fresh squeezed lemon juice if you have it available. It's good with the reconstituted too but the fresh will about knock your socks off it's so good! This recipe is quick & easy & simply put, the best.
It's pretty simple and basic. I spice it up with extra garlic, Maybe some green Olives or roasted red peppers.
Excellent hummus. I made some before using dry beans, but this was so much better not to mention a lot quicker.

Easy and delicious! Definitely a keeper and so much cheaper and quicker than getting fresh from the Middle Eastern restaurants or market. This has a deeper flavor than the store bought as well, and you can make it creamier by adding in more tahini and blending longer. I would suggest keeping some of the chickpea juice to use as needed to suit your liking as far as thickness of the hummus goes.
Delicious!
Roasted garlic, added Serrano pepper so delicious

We tried another recipe that didn't contain Tahini along with this one.
This one definitely had a more well rounded and delicious flavor. We left off the parsley and paprika. We'll probably include the paprika next time but I doubt the parsley will make a comeback.
This came out amazing! I made the tahini recipe on this site to make this hummus. It’s delicious and looks beautiful. So proud of it!
Haven't made this ages, til I ran across Tahini in the grocery store. It's just as good as I remember from way back when.
We're big fans of garlic so I used a really big clove, but it is delicious.

Our family prefers blending half of the olive oil in the dip with a few ice Cubes. Then using the reminding olive oil to garnish. 
If kids will be enjoying the dip reduce garlic or omit completely.

Serve with carrots, Persian cucumbers, pita chips or pita bread.
We make this healthy snack often!
Loved it!
This recipe was easy to make. I love a lot of garlic so I added 10 cloves instead of 2. I'll probably use 7-8 new time. It was a hit at Thanksgiving.

First time ever making hummus and I was surprised how easy it was. Followed the recipe exactly. Could just a bit of the liquid maybe from the beans or lemons. I think from now on I will make it instead of buying it.
DELICIOUS!!!
Added fresh parsley from the garden. Delicious and refreshing on a hot day.
Delicious, I would like it a bit more on the creamy side.

I added extra lemon juice, because more sour is better. I used a 16 Oz bag of dried chickpeas, and soaked it overnight. It wasn’t quite as soaked as I needed so I made it 48 hours later. It absorbed water to make 4 cups, so double the recipe. If using canned it might whip up faster. 

I bet if you had really expensive great olive oil it would be fragrant! I had cheap olive oil, which made an average hummus, nothing different than store-bought except I saved money and there are no chemical preserves in it. Just salt. That makes it 5 stars. 

I used a Nutrabullet to make this. 

I bet this will be good on gyros, but it’s good like this on pita and salsa. Enjoy!

I used cooked garbanzos, rather than from can so maybe mine weren't as soft to start. 
 I added water for easier blending and a bit more salt to my taste. Excellent recipe. 

Roasted garlic added a nice touch and if you don't like the smokiness of paprika, any other favorite spice will work. I used cayenne and a dash or turmeric instead.

This was easy & a good recipe to start off with. I added additional garlic & lemon juice. It reminded me of the street hummus I had in Israel in my teens, but wasn't quite as good. One thing I suggest is to make sure all the skins are off the beans before putting them in the food processor.
I removed the husks from each bean before tossing into the food processor. Added more olive oil for some viscosity.
The recipe as written simply doesn’t have enough liquid to blend properly. Since I didn’t have time to read all the comments before making this, it was frustrating. Can’t recommend as written.
Amazing! I added 1/2 teaspoon of cumin and 1/8 teal
Yum! I added Cumin too, and extra lemon juice. Delicious and fluffy. Was a hit.
Excellent and tasty! Added 1/4c water to help with blending. Also added some cumin. Delicious.
I followed the recipe but did look at the reviews and added a bit of liquid and some cayenne. Definitely is a keeper!

This is a very good hummus recipe. Two comments: Beware, some chick peas are packed with a lot of salt. Check the list of ingredients on the can. (I recommend TJ's organic chick peas.) Better yet, buy dry chick peas, cook them the day before and let them cool over night. Save the water to add to the hummus if it is too dry. Good additions are black olives or roasted sweet pepper.

This hummus is so disgustingly lemon it ruined the whole batch for me, I DO NOT recommend this recipe to anyone. Only use about a couple tablespoons and would have been fine but it is wayy to much lemon!
This is the most delicious hummus I have ever tasted
This was fine as a very basic bland recipe, I used suggestions to pump up the flavor, but all in all it lacked depth, it was smooth and I could see using it as a base for a richly flavored hummus.
Delicious and super simple! I just added extra olive oil, because I that is just how I like it...

This was my first time making hummus. I used 1 can of garbanzos (1.5c), so I cut back on the other ingredients to make a smaller amount. I made it as described except for accidentally mixing in the olive oil. It was good but very thick. Next time I will add liquid to see if I can get it creamier, and maybe something to give it a little kick.
I really liked this recipe. I used roasted garlic instead of raw. It was really creamy and flavorful.
Tastes best thinner a little with water and warmed.
I forgot to add the tahini ( was making 3 different things ) and it is still outstanding , in fact I would leave it out. Blows any store-bought away , not even close .

Absolutely delicious. I’ve made about ten different kinds of hummus, even one from a famous cooking show. None were as good as this, in fact we never even finished the others. I used Goya Chick peas and Joyva Tahina. Two big garlic cloves 3 Tblspn of lemon juice, this was to our taste.

This is my go-to hummus recipe. Yes, I adapt it a bit according to my taste like many others here have suggested. It's a great place to start. I have even had to substitute white beans for the garbanzos/chickpeas and it was still good!
Excellent
Will definitely make again as I have before. Added a few Manzanilla and Kalamata olives for extra punch. Awesome!
Came out great - very easy!
Excellent flavor, great taste with the lemon juice.

I made it as written, and added 2 extra cloves of garlic, 1/2 tsp cumin, 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes, 2 tsp plain yogurt to make it creamier and substituted the parsley with cilantro. (we like spicy!) It was delicious! Thank you for a great recipe!
So simple and absolutely delicious for the whole family! I added the garlic, lemon and tahini to taste, and probably used a bit extra of all of them. TY!
Great, traditional hummus recipe.
Delicious and easy!
Simple and delicious!

This is always my GO-TO recipe for hummus. I love reading all the reviews. To me , you either love hummus or you don't. Hummus is very forgiving and flexible. I like to spice it up with extra garlic (double or triple the recommendation). Tahineh can be tricky and can go rancid if not properly stored and used. Some people also forget to mix it VERY well before using. If you have thick paste at the bottom keep stirring. I also fold in the tahineh at the end and give it as few spins in the food processor as possible. I heard it can cause mixture to "glutenize" if blended too long.
This hummus has become a staple in my house. Everyone loves it and it's super easy to make. I actually have to make it every week because the whole batch is always eaten.
I used 2 cans of beans and added the olive oil and some parsley into the mix. I also added some tabasco- Yummy- better than store bought!

I followed other reviewers and added only 1 TBLS of toasted sesame seed oil as I didn’t have any tahini, I thought it worked well. I didn’t have any Meyer lemon so I added regular fresh lemon and thought the final result was a bit too lemony. Next time I’ll reduce the lemon juice to one cup. Also, I added 3 TBLS of extra virgin olive oil to help thin it out and while I thought that was the perfect amount my Greek husband thought I could add more. Overall, good solid recipe to start with!

My can of garbanzo beans held 1.5 cups so I started with 1/4 cup think and 3 tbsp of lemon juice. I should have saved the can juice but I didn't. Reduced the salt but not the garlic. I thinned it with half lemon juice and half water. We'll see how it mellows in a few hours! I may start making this one a lot! Loved the comment about freezing it in a cupcake pan, and the one about adding roasted red pepper. I forsee taste tests!
So good and easy! I didn’t have garlic cloves so used garlic powder. Probably will be even better with fresh garlic! But his is yummy!

When we made this, my wife added a Jamaican touch by adding one large, ripe avocado, 1 cup of black beans, 6 drops of scotch bonnet sauce, 1/4 teaspoon curry powder. 2 tablespoons of coconut paste and some chopped red and yellow peppers. Puree the whole lot in food processor, place in food storage container and store in the fridge overnight to let everything blend together. Serve as usual. Hope you enjoy.
Great receipt. I will try some of the suggestions and just play with it a little, but this receipt is a keeper.
This was great - so fresh and so much better than store-bought. Also easy to make and cost effective. Will make it again!
Delicious!
Amazing - as good as any restaurant hummus and way better than store-bought!
My friends and I really liked it, but found the sesame taste a little strong. I may use less tahini next time.

We made this tonight and liked the base recipe, we did make a few adjustments for our tastes. We added cumin for a little extra zing, and used the aqua faba to thin it a bit. Added a little garlic powder as well, and we loved it. Thanks for the base recipe.
Wow, What a simple satisfying dip for chips. Taste is amazing

I just made this & it is excellent. I only have a small blender so it was a bit more challenging to grind up the beans. I used 1 can of garbanzo beans & adjusted everything else accordingly. Fortunately I had all the ingredients on hand so no need to buy anything else. I would like to try it with some sun dried tomatoes some time.
Great recipe. Perfect pitas. If you don’t have a bread making machine just let dough rise for one hour.

Excellent recipe. I only altered the recipe in one way: I used cooked dried beans instead of canned. I saved some of the cooking water to thin the mixture and it's perfect! Thank you for sharing this recipe.

This stuff is delicious! I halved the recipe as there are just two of us eating it, but wow....we used baby carrots and sweet red pepper for dippers. Thank you so much for this excellent recipe, it’s a keeper for sure. Fast and easy to make.

OK, kids. Tahini is just ground sesame seeds. You can make it in a coffee grinder or mortar & pestle. This is a good recipe because it lists all the essential ingredients for hummus, not necessarily because its ratios are perfect for everyone. My absolute favorite kind of hummus is one I invented and therefore can’t be found in stores: sweet & spicy chili basil! Add a couple tablespoons of garlic chili sauce (Asian market) and a handful or 2 of basil leaves (Thai is better but Italian works in a pinch, but they MUST be fresh). Since there’s garlic in the chili sauce, I don’t add raw garlic to this kind of hummus. Instead, I use either roasted fresh garlic or a tablespoon of Better than Bullion Roasted Garlic Base. And I like half lemon half lime juice and a few drops of lemon extract, but that’s personal preference. Also, if your lemons aren’t ripe... don’t blame the recipe.
I loved it. I made my own tahini. The consistency was firmer than usual but very flavorful
Taste delicious I didn’t have lemon juice so i took real lemons and made lemon juice came out great. I also like a little more garlic so I used olive oil with garlic and added two more cloves.
Delicious! Will make it again and again. Thx!

A couple issues for me: I made this first with canned beans and today with dry beans that I de-skinned; the latter is by far a better, smoother texture with a fresher taste, so if you have time, try it if you eat a lot of hummus. The recipe seemed a bit bland as written the first time I followed it, so the second time, I added 1 T EVOO and 1 T smoked paprika while blending, then topped with pine nuts and another sprinkle of the paprika. The additions livened the flavor, so that's preference.
Good, i added a 1/2 cup of olive oil tho.

If you don't like the gritty texture, here's a modification for super smooth hummus: boil the canned beans for 20 minutes in water and 1/2 tsp of baking soda. Rinse and drain the beans. 

Pay attention to the ingredients list. I almost put in 2 CANS of beans. It calls for 2 cups. Measure them, one can equaled 1 1/2 cups, but another brand had a lot less beans in the can.
 
Put all the ingredients except the beans in first, blend them, then add the warm beans after you have rinsed off the baking soda water and drained them.
I added leftover roasted vegetables and it was great.
Great every time!!!

Alway remove the skin from the beans before putting it in the processor. Yes it makes mincemeat of the skin, but the skin has a off taste. In the Middle East the skin is always removed from the bean but they don’t normally use a food processor either. 
Otherwise the recipe is great. I always add Zatar and pine nuts on top
Super easy recipe, quick to execute and delicious! I liked the texture and the paprika on top was a nice addition.
It was very good. This was my first attempt at homemade hummus. Now I feel confident enough to try making other flavors. Thanks for such an easy and tasty recipe.

Agree this is a great foundational recipe. I started from dried chickpeas just because I had them on hand—and an Instant Pot, so 22 minutes under high pressure and then 20 minutes natural release. After cooling I used 2 3/4 cups of the chickpeas, 3 cloves garlic, 1/4 cup lemon juice. I added 1/3 cup tahini because I like it more than most. I added 14 t
Made it as written-in a word wonderful. Used some roasted garlic I made the day before . Hope this makes it till halftime
Good recipe
it was really good mmm

The recipe as written is pretty bland, but it's a good base. I cooked my own chickpeas so I knew exactly how they were prepared. After trying the recipe as written, I doubled the salt, lemon juice, and garlic and added 1tsp of toasted sesame oil and blended all together. I would use this recipe as a go-to starter, but it definitely needs some adjustments to give it flavor.
Just added a little water to get the blender to keep moving! More lemon, because I love it. I’ll make this often, as I keep frozen made-from-dry chickpeas.
So easy, tasty and quick for a nutritous snack or appy.
Added a couple of rehydrated New Mexico chilies, turned out pretty good.
Reduced lemon juice by half and have made it with or without the tahini with good results!
Delicious!!

This is a very good hummus! It tastes better than anything that I have bought in the store and super easy. I made my own tahini by putting roasted sesame seeds in the food processor and slowly adding olive oil. I will make this again. Thank you for the base recipe.
Maybe a little bit olive oil need to be added, only tahini makes the mixture too heavy to process ... but the taste is OK.
Made it it was fabulous, need to cut back on the tahini, it was very powerful flavor, can’t wait to make it again

I've been into hummus lately and I made this on a whim. It's so delicious! I can't quite pinpoint why, maybe it's the fresh lemon juice. I don't know if I will be buying hummus in the store anymore. My only suggestion is to keep the juice from the chickpeas to make the hummus more of it's traditional consistency, instead of a paste which is what I ended up with.

It was pretty great. I made it exactly like the recipe and received rave reviews from friends. However, next time I will adjust proportions to fit my small food processor. Two cups garbanzo beans is about a can (15 oz) and a half which pushed my appliance to the max. I'll adjust the recipe a bit to work for just a single 15 oz can of garbanzo beans.

Mr. Yum Yum will never buy hummus from the store again! This was absolutely divine. The ingredients blend into the most superb flavor and texture. Next time, I might try adding some pesto and pine nuts, or sun-dried tomatoes. This is a great base, and most excellent on it's own. Mr. Yum Yum gives this 5 mashallas!
